# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Here is an example of how you could solve this problem in Julia:

```julia
using DataFrames, Tables

function audi_filter(df::DataFrame)
    # Filter the data frame to only include rows with manufacturer "audi" and model "a4 or a4 quattro"
    df = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df)
    
    # Add a new column that equals true across all rows
    push!(df, :audi_a4_type => true)

    return df
end
```
This function first uses the `filter` function from DataFrames to filter out any rows where the manufacturer is not "audi" or the model is not "a4" or "a4 quattro". Then it adds a new column named `audi_a4_type` that equals true for all rows.

You can use this function like so:
```julia
df = DataFrame(manufacturer = ["audi", "bmw", "toyota", "audi", "audi"], model = ["a4", "a3", "corolla", "a4 quattro", "a5"])
new_df = audi_filter(df)
```
This will give you a new DataFrame that only includes rows where the manufacturer is "audi" and the model is either "a4" or "a4 quattro". The new column `audi_a4_type` will be true for all of these rows.
